column4: ok so i can' t ssh into my box from my external ip, but i CAN ssh into it via its local address. i have the ports forarded and i've even tried to put it in dmz. any suggestions?
but, if you can access ssh from the local network, 192.168.0.0/24 or whatever, you problem probably lies in the router somewhere... that or your ISP is blocking 22 from somewhere in their systems
i've talked to my isp, it's not blocked there

make absolute sure you're using the *right* external IP address, especially if your Internet comes from DSL and PPPoE etc... they use several IP's that seem external, when one of them is the actual 'external' ip
and i have the damned ports forwarded. i even put it in the dmz.
you could even consider putting your modem in a switch mode to bypass the router features, thereby removing that obvious obstacle... i used to do that with Embarq DSL
i'm not using my modem's router function. it's a satellite connection and it's a very basic modem.
good luck with satellite.  i've never encountered a satellite ISP that actually provided a useable external IP... especially those ******* over at HughesNet
how can one or another IP be more or less useable?

trust me... those satellite people are crazy and downright evil.  i will no longer discuss this matter considering the fact that you are using satellite internet.  this is for my sanity's sake.  trust me.
lol ok. i can move the server to my dad's house, i guess. thats good advice though, thank you.

i once spent over 16 hours of time, total, arguing with a satellite provider i was paying over $4500 / mo. about how they were throttling our bandwidth, specifically, so that i could manage our bandwidth usage accordingly.  they preferred me to be confused, so they could throttle me endlessly...

in the end, thoough, i figured out how to keep tc/ip/iptables/brtables/etc... working such that internet worked reliably over satellite... no thanks to those jerks on the other end though, with their endlessly overfilling bucket of pain and suffering (they scraped off the most needed bits first of course>>>)
loll well if you had the godly grace to write a howto on all that i'd love to read it someday
but, you *can* run a SSH reverse tunnel and run a proxy from a location external to the satellite connection thereby reliably offering a connection
hey! reverse ssh tunnel! i read an article on that earlier today
then, from the external server, you can run a sort of SSH proxy
piece of cake.  and, you can even write simple scripts that will attempt to create the tunnel whenever you want, cron fun
